direction.raw_text: 20s, paces a corner, restless, looking for action ... wet hair, three-day beard, trenchcoat, sneakers, heat-seeking weary eyes. He flashes a wad of bills in an effort to get some attention... no one notices. Across the street, BILL RICE, 50's, a ragged transient, strolls over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rice starts away.   Reilly pauses, then trudges after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Know what the problem is, kid?   You're too ugly to get propositioned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   SIDESTREET - NIGHT                                     2 Rice and Reilly pull donuts and coffee out of a bag, talk with their mouths full as they walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They share a grin, pass a BAG LADY who wears a pie-tin crown, holding her hand out to a PIMP getting into a Cadillac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small gift, sir, for the Queen ... The Pimp ignores her, screeches off. The Bag Lady pulls out a pad, adds his license number to a list, glances up at Rice and Reilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I keep a record, see? They don't pay, I don't forget. Rice fishes some change out of his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here you go, your Highness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, officer. She pushes her shopping cart away. Rice and Reilly look at each other, crack up, surprised she knew he was a cop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what'll you do? After they give you the gold watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, I got a gold watch... it just don't work. Maybe they'll give me a new fishing pole, or something useful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't fish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How hard can it be? The grand kids been buggin' me about taking them camping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop beside a dirty, beat-up Studebaker parked in the alley, climb in, Reilly behind the wheel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Next week we work the park.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta get back on top.   Get off the sleaze detail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will, one day at a time.   I'll be old and grey when it happens...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You outta the city... that's a fish out of water. What's with all this family talk lately, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of these days you're gonna get tired of fighting the shit. When that happens, you'll wish you had family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks.   I got close but it never woulda worked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cluttered with debris - clothes, boxes, personal items. Reilly jiggles the ignition - the engine coughs and sputters, finally turns over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The White Van appears up ahead and turns into a seemingly deserted building's garage. Reilly and Rice exchange a glance as they wait to see lights come on in the building. They don't. Two flashlight beams criss cross through the windows of the building briefly, then disappear. They hear a brief heated argument, that is cut short abruptly. Then silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly jumps out and heads for the building.   Rice rolls his eyes, follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you just shoot it and put it out of its misery?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about, it's purring like a kitty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you said what's-her-name's brother was going to fix it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She didn't work out, had to cut her loose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She wanted to cook me breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're vice, I didn't see no pimps or hookers in that van. But if you're so gung-ho, we'd best call it in for some back-up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah, let's just take a look-see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   BUILDING - NIGHT                                         4 A huge, old, battered machine shop. Spooky darkness, dead quiet. Moonlight filters in through dirt-smeared windows. The door CREAKS as Reilly and Rice slip in, stop, eyes scan. Nothing.   Just rows of glistening machines. Rice gestures for Reilly to spread out. They head in, footsteps echoing, shadows washing over them. Still nothing...deeper, deeper... then, glancing over, Reilly sees a shape hiding behind a machine. He steps towards it. The shape whirls - a beautiful spitfire of a GIRL with piercing blue eyes. She tries to bolt. Reilly grabs her. She struggles, pulls a knife, slashes his arm, drawing blood through his trenchcoat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow!   Son-of-a-bitch. He punches her full force in the face - she collapses, knocked out cold. Rice rushes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, just a nick ... Then, over Reilly's shoulder, Rice sees a dark SILHOUETTE emerging from behind a machine. Rice draws his pistol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Freeze!   Police! As Reilly whirls, the Silhouette raises a Mac-11. Rice shoves Reilly aside as the Silhouette OPENS FIRE... Diving for cover, Reilly flings back his trenchcoat, whips out his 9mm and RETURNS FIRE at the Silhouette, blowing the shit out of windows behind, sparks showering off machines. Silence for an instant, Reilly looks for Rice and finds him bleeding to death on the floor nearby - he is completely exposed to the line of fire. The Silhouette and another FIGURE OPEN FIRE on Reilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 40s, crazy-brilliant, manic eyes... and one of his men, pale, sweaty, wearing an EARRING, 30s, continue the barrage. Swan fires ONE SHOT at a time at Rice, deliberately aiming not to kill him, trying to flush Reilly out. Rice screams as BULLETS RIP into his legs. Reilly tries to reach him but can't, shots forcing him back. A dark-eyed man with a BEARD appears in the b.g. and stealths towards Reilly from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Reilly' face is in agony as Rice moans in pain. He glances urgently from the gunmen to the exit behind them, to The Girl lying next to him -- what's keeping them there? Obviously The Girl. She stirs. Desperate, Reilly grabs her by the hair, shoves his 9mm to her head. Using her as a shield, he drags her in front of Rice to protect him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drop it! Swan's eyes flare. He steps out into the open, gun aimed at Rice, eyes locked murderously on Reilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let her go. Reilly cocks his hammer, fingers trembling.   The Girl stiffens, terrified. Beard emerges behind Reilly. Deadly silent, he raises an automatic, trying to get a clear shot between machines...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, the girl! Reilly whirls, sees Beard, shrinks back to stay covered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We gotta get outta here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell them to drop it - now! A deadly stalemate.   Faraway SIRENS WAIL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have no idea how sorry you're going to be. (to The Girl) Don't worry. Beard smolders, Earring sweats. Keeping their guns up, the three men grab tool bags, work their way to the alley door and slip out. The moment they're gone, Reilly quickly handcuffs The Girl to a machine, kneels, cradles Rice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take your time... one day at a time, kid... Rice takes Reilly's hand and pats it on his wristwatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all I got... it's yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It don't work-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ain't that a shit-- Rice's eyes go blank, he exhales his last breath. Reilly winces, eyes welling up. His gaze moves at the Girl. The Girl stares uncomfortably, a blink of sympathy stealing past her hard exterior ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE HEADQUARTERS - MORNING                            5 Looking numb, out of place, Rice's blood still on his trenchcoat, Reilly walks in, weaves through a chaos of ringing phones, overworked cops, suspects being booked. Cops look up, whisper about him. Turning a corner, Reilly bumps into a bulldog of a cop,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hustling The Girl out of a booking room. She's got a shiner where Reilly hit her. The Girl and Reilly make eye contact, intimate somehow, a flash of vulnerability and fear in The Girl's face...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly snaps out of it, continues on.    Reilly nods as Harry hustles the girl away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Reilly, Captain's looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - DAY                                   6 Behind his desk, a work-weary captain, WINTERS, 50s, sucks coffee as he grills ARTIE PLUCHINSKY, 40s, a slick suit-and- tie homicide detective.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly, what the hell happened out there?   Why didn't you call for back-up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I-- Reilly looks at his watch (we notice he's now wearing Rice's watch). He taps it, listens to see if it's ticking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dammit, Rice was a good man,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to work this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're vice, not homicide. Besides, you don't have the experience and you're too personally involved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But sir--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know the rules. You're off the street `til I.A.D. clears the investigation. Now go home and clean yourself up, get some rest... Harry barges in, dumps a bag of personal effects on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She won't talk. Look at this shit, no I.D., nothing... Reilly picks up a twisted plastic-wire bracelet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly sears into Pluchinsky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters eyes him for a beat, relents...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly spins and exits quickly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lab's backed up, we're still waiting for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like the stuff my dad used to use to blow up tree stumps back in Scranton.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe she knows your old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it down to the Bomb Squad, Artie-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, kid.    Run this down to the Cave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE STATION - BASEMENT - DAY                          7 Emerging from a dingy back staircase, Reilly enters a hallway and moves to a door a door marked "BOMB SQUAD."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE STATION - "THE CAVE" - DAY                        8 Reilly enters into another world - a dungeon cluttered with bomb paraphernalia, defusing equipment, a dog house, ping- pong table, Sheryl Crow pin-up, Chicago Bears posters, Yassir Arafat dartboard, a photo-shrine to dead Bomb Squaders. A plain, fresh-faced assistant, BEV, 30s, looks up from her computer station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly sprints out.   Bev tries to finish but he's gone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm looking for the Bomb Squad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There out on a call, perhaps I can help you-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: block of Lakefront.   A limousine.   But, I- REILLY Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CITY STREETS - DAY                                         9 The Studebaker coughs and smokes in and out of traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   LAKEFRONT STREET - DAY                                  10 A young, uniformed police OFFICER stops Reilly in front of a cordoned-off section of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bomb Squad. The Officer nods and moves the barricade out of the way, Reilly hits the gas, rumbles through. The Studebaker swings past a fire truck, an ambulance, and two squads cars. Two OFFICERS stand near a building with a worried BUSINESSMAN and his CHAUFFEUR. Reilly parks 50 yards from a limo stopped in the middle of the street. A Bomb Squad van and sleek black Harley Davidson parked beyond it. Reilly hops out, heads cautiously for the limo
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 50s, a barrel-chested ex-football player is on his hands and knees looking under the limo. Red rubber ball in hand, Hawaiian shirt half-tucked in, he leads around an equally scruffy Labrador Retriever, SCHNOZ.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smell anything, Schnoz?    Me, neither. T.J., 20s, a country boy inspects the open trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 40s, clean-cut, straight-laced, easy-going smile, brilliant leader of the team, steps lightly around the open driver's door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schnoz, come here, boy. T.J. Shhh, I hear something.... Reilly stands off 25 feet.    Glass notices him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the heck're you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You the Bomb Squad? T.J. No, we're terrorists, stay back or we'll blow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're a bit busy at the moment, I'll give you a statement in a few minutes if we're still alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly, Vice. I- T.J. Quiet! Glass and Pooch step lightly to the rear of the limo where T.J. has discovered a shoebox wedged next to the spare tire. T.J. leans down, puts his ear to it, nods. T.J. (cont.) Ticker. Pooch lifts up Schnoz and holds him over the trunk.    Schnoz sniffs the shoebox, whines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schnoz says it's loaded.    Good boy, Schnozzie. Pooch lowers Schnoz back to the ground throws him the red ball, and trots back to the van, climbs up inside and sits, watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright boys, look close.   Let's assess. Glass, Pooch and T.J. take a beat just to look at the shoebox. Then, Glass nods for Reilly to move away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Reilly takes a few steps back, watching as the team works together - Glass in charge - a psychic connection between them as they pass tools back and forth like surgeons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass puts on magnifying spectacles -- precise, organized, a detail freak as he uses a wooden probe to test the box for wires, sensors. As the others watch, Glass rubs his fingertips ritualistically and carefully eases the top off the box. He reaches in...   Grabs something...   Slowly pulls it out ... It's a Mickey Mouse alarm clock doll, a clump of unlit firecrackers taped between Mickey's legs. The Bomb Squaders whoop and howl - all except Pooch who pulls out a pack of Tums, shoves half of it in his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all crack up, hysterical.   Reilly stares in disbelief -- these guys are nuts! 11   MOMENTS LATER - AT THE BOMB SQUAD VAN                             11 In the b.g., the Officers finish getting a statement from the Businessman as the still-worried Chauffeur inspects the limo. T.J. and Pooch load their equipment into the van as Glass fills out paperwork. T.J. That guy's wife must be pretty pissed off to play a trick like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No shit.   I better send Meg flowers just in case. T.J. and Pooch share a laugh as Reilly approaches...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's in charge here? Pooch points to Schnoz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, it's important. T.J. Make an appointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's about this. Reilly holds up the bracelet.    Glass takes it, frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you get this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Off a girl's wrist.    A suspect... T.J. P.E.T.N ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: High-grade det cord. This girl, either she's got strange taste in jewelry or she's into serious demolition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean? Glass whips out a blasting cap from his utility belt, cuts off a piece of the bracelet, plugs it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fire in the hole! Glass tosses it into a sewer drain. A beat, then a small
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: smoke billows out of the gutter drain. The nearby Officers jump, alarmed. The Bomb Squad guys laugh. Glass waves to the Officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry about that. (to Reilly) That's an inch of the stuff, imagine what the whole thing'd do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. He grabs back the bracelet, turns to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey wait a minute- Reilly jogs back to his Studebaker, climbs in and roars off in a cloud of dirty smoke. T.J. Vice... Jesus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That'd be some explosive pussy he's got his hands on. Pooch and T.J. share a laugh as Glass shakes his head, climbs on his Harley. The others pile into the van. Glass kicks-starts his hog and rumbles away, van following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BAR - DAY                                                  12 Thin crowd of day-time drinkers. Earring walks in, moves to a booth where Swan and Beard are eating. Earring pulls out a Gallois (French) cigarette, lights up from a book of matches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Earring shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swan slams his fist down, spilling food.     No one in bar even looks up from their drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Earring stares uneasily. Swan and Beard look up, freeze.     A pair of PATROL COPS are heading directly towards them. Earring reaches under his jacket...   Swan grabs Earring's arm, calming him. The Cops keep coming, then at the last moment, they veer left and slide into a booth. Swan nods, they get up and casually slip outside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If you'd let me waste him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I say we split town. Come back to this job when things cool. We've got other contracts - Denver, Seattle...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want her back and we do the job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we agreed, the personal can't interfere with the professional.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides, we're on a schedule and the cops won't let her go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE STATION - SQUAD ROOM - DAY                         13 Reilly hurries in, interrupts Winters and Pluchinsky talking over Pluchinsky's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An OFFICER shouts from across the room, holding up a phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters snatches up the nearest phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He listens, facial expression changing, getting tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What...? He punches an intercom button - the whole room stops, looks up, as Swan's voice comes over the squawk box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said release the girl or alot of people are going to die. Winters signals frantically for the call to be traced -- cops spring into action.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's exactly two o'clock. If she's not released in one hour, people die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, what do you mean--? Click, the line goes dead.    Winters slams down the phone - no chance of a trace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ticking bomb...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's detonation cord, for a bomb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly takes off, Pluchinsky glares.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Reilly) I thought I told you--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He says it's important, something about the Rice shooting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a bluff. The guy's full of crap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can't take the chance. Ring down to the Bomb Squad. I want them on alert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I saw these guys, I can i.d. them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you're anxious to get back but... just stay out of homicide's way or I'll have you classifying fingerprints, understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   THE CAVE - DAY                                           14 T.J. is hunched over a twisted mess of wires, untangling them.   Pooch taste-tests dog biscuits for Schnoz, then feeds them to him, as he talks to his wife on the phone. Glass is dissecting the Mickey Mouse clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bev glances longingly at T.J. as she gives Glass a neck rub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . T.J. Hey, I'm next. T.J. winks as Bev turns away, hard to get. Reilly bursts in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, that's the guy-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We just got a bomb threat upstairs. This gets everyone's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cop was killed last night interrupting a robbery. One of the gang was grabbed, a girl. The one I told you about with the detonation cord. Well, her friends just called in, they're threatening to waste people unless she's released in the next hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright, let's check it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can start in the area where the robbery occurred. T.J. Vice cop on a homicide?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain assigned me to assist you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Assist?   What the hell you know about tickers anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easy, guys. (to Reilly) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, nothing personal, but you can't just waltz in here and expect to join the team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you need us, you love us, when you don't, we're shunned by the rest of the department.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got one hour.     Are you coming or not? The Squad just stands there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, fuck you. Reilly walks out.   The guys look at each other.   Glass frowns at the bracelet. T.J. Those vice cops, around all that pussy, so pent up. Bev smirks at T.J.'s language, he lowers his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call upstairs, see what you can find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: T.J., run a trace on this, see if you can pin down where it came from. Whoever these people are, let's hope they're all talk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, honey, I'm fine. Yeah, well, you're welcome. You deserve flowers more often.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   ALLEY - DAY                                             15 Reilly's Studebaker is parked next to the machine shop building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BUILDING - MACHINE SHOP - DAY                           16 Reilly enters and slowly re-walks his steps from the shoot- out, pausing over the chalk outline of Rice's body. Two FORENSICS OFFICERS silently comb over the crime scene. Reilly pauses, sadness overwhelming him. One of the Officers nods at him, he has to turn away as the emotions come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   SUNCREST MOTEL - ROOM - DAY                             17 Sophisticated detonation equipment and weapons cover the beds. Beard scowls, Earring sweats as Swan puts the finishing touches on a computerized briefcase bomb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sets a timer, closes the briefcase, smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Swan, it's no use. Look, we can still make Houston--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   SUNCREST MOTEL - DAY                                    18 Sleazy area. Briefcase in hand, Earring slips out and blends into pedestrian traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BUSY STREET - DAY                                        19 Earring walks on, just a man with a briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   ANOTHER STREET - DAY                                     20 Earring slows and passes a bus stop where a group of giggly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are waiting. He notices a raven-haired KNOCKOUT going into the pub up ahead. He grins and follows her in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PUB - DAY                                                21 A trendy Irish Pub, a sparse lunch crowd. Earring enters, spots the Knockout ordering a drink at the bar, slides onto a stool next to her, and deposits the briefcase on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives him a once-over, turns up her nose, nods a `thanks' to the Bartender delivering her white wine. Earring's smile doesn't change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Earring grins and shrugs an `oh well'. He slides off the stool, steps back, and exits... leaving the briefcase behind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, beautiful, can I buy you some bangers and mash? Pint of Guiness?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) Last chance. You know, even the smallest choices in life could change everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Earring walks out and strolls off. He checks his watch, picks up the pace. He disappears around a corner. Cars pass.   People stroll by.   Nothing happens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . An ordinary scene on an ordinary day.     The silence is screaming. Suddenly - the bar EXPLODES. A FIREBALL BURSTS OUT the front window, showering the street with wood and BROKEN GLASS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BAR - DAY - LATER                                          22 Chaotic aftermath of the bombing... sirens, flashing red lights. Police hold back onlookers, Firemen clean up, Paramedics carry corpses and moaning Victims out of the charred, smoking ruins, into waiting ambulances. A black-and-white tears up. Capt. Winters leaps out, pushes through to a dirt-covered FIRE CHIEF.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters looks grim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly SCREECHES up in his Studebaker, jumps out, pushes through, flashes his badge, enters the police zone. He stops as he sees a bloody FEMALE VICTIM being loaded into an ambulance. Suddenly a voice snaps him out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly faces him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly ignores them, starts towards the ruins.    Pluchinsky shoves him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You touch me again and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what, you'll shoot me? Hey, don't mistake me for one of your partners, I'd like to make retirement in one piece. Pluchinsky starts to laugh as Reilly pops him once hard in the face. Pluchinsky staggers backwards, grasping his bleeding nose. Reilly is ready for more as Pluchinsky starts at him. They exchange a few body shots before several cops swarm in and pull them apart. Winters hustles over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son-of-a-bitch... my nose...   This fuck-up is interfering with-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly, what're you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I told you--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's with us. They all turn. Glass and T.J. stand there, soot-smeared, wearing utility belts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We asked him to come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . T.J. Yeah, he's helping us work up a profile on this thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hope you don't mind, Captain, might help us catch these guys that much sooner. (to Reilly) Coming? Reilly looks at the Captain awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead, kid. Reilly marches after Glass and T.J., leaving Pluchinsky fuming, holding closed his bloody nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm filing charges against that mother-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can it, Pluchinsky. And shove some cotton up your nose.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) I said get the fuck outta here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Reilly follows Glass and T.J., bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was-?   Why...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That cop who bought it... you didn't tell us he was your partner. T.J. We've lost brothers too, we know what that's like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly glares, tongue-tied, as they walk past the Bomb Squad van and Glass' Harley, enter the wreckage.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get something straight. We're doing you a favor. You're not exactly a guy we want around explosives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't bumper cars, it's brain surgery. You wanna work with us, you do it our way, understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be cool around my men, they don't trust strangers. And try not to swear so much, it's unattractive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   PUB - DAY                                               24 Smoky hell. Two Firemen drag out a fire hose. Glass, T.J. and Reilly approach a taped-off area where Pooch is on his hands and knees, wet and dirty as he searchs for clues. Schnoz sits nearby, red ball in his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly avoids the hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That there's Schnoz, mascot and ace bomb sniffer. Say hi, Schnozzie. Schnoz ignores them, sniffing a charred beam in a corner. T.J. points out burn patterns to Glass. T.J. Flame racer, partial P.C.L. See this wave pattern? Definitely self-contained. Pooch sniffs dirt, tastes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nitro, dash of Semtrex, vegetable oil ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of bomb was it? T.J. Device.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't use the b-word.      Bad luck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you're the "Device Squad"... and you defuse "devices"?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treat.    We treat devices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything else I should know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't push it, slick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Schnoz whines and paws at something under the beam.   They scramble over. T.J. Pooch, can you move it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... Pooch positions himself like a weight-lifter preparing to dead-lift. He growls as he strains to lift the beam out of the way. Glass and T.J. jump in and go to work with toothbrushes and tweezers. As Reilly watches, fascinated, they uncover a scorched fragment of a briefcase handle. T.J. Yes, baby, yes ... Pooch throws Schnoz the red ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good boy, Schnoz. Daddy loves you. T.J. Scorch marks... looks like they used silly putty. Reilly looks to Glass for an explanation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: plastic explosive. T.J. Helluva fuck factor. Reilly again looks for an explanation. T.J. (cont.) Don't worry, you'll pick it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something glitters in the ashes. Pooch picks it up with tweezers. A tiny chip. The guys stare at it, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass takes it, puts on his magnifying spectacles, holds it up to the light, frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pooch and T.J. go back to searching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass turns to see Reilly on his way out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: By the way, I'm Glass.   This is T.J., and Pooch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mike Reilly. T.J. (offering dirty hand) Uh-huh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unlikely. Probably, cash register or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) What can you tell us about the girl with the exploding jewelry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE HEADQUARTERS - DAY                              25 Phones are ringing off the hook. Reilly bursts in, notices Winters directing an army of cops setting up sophisticated tracing equipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Reilly discreetly crosses the room but is intercepted by Pluchinsky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were lucky today, vice boy. Captain said to leave it alone, but just remember, I'm watching you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, detective, but you're just not my type. Pluchinsky's face turns red with rage as... An OFFICER holds up a phone urgently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain, it's him! The room scrambles into action as Winters grabs the phone. Swan's voice crackles over the squawk box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't make me send another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, we're prepared to talk, what do you want--? Click, dial tone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?   Hello? Winters slams down the receiver. Cops pull off their tracing headphones, glance at each other uneasily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Section commanders, in my office, now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As the room erupts, Reilly turns to the BOOKING OFFICER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly takes off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go, we gotta jump on him the second he calls again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's the girl? The one I brought in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE STATION - INTERROGATION VIEWING BOOTH - DAY      26 Wearing headphones connected to a tape recorder, a BORED COP flips wearily through a comic book in front of a one-way mirror. Through it can be seen a bare interrogation room where The Girl sits stubbornly at a table across from Harry. Stubbing a butt into an overflowing ashtray, Harry rubs the back of his neck, gets up and goes through a door, into the viewing booth. The Bored Cop looks up, shuts off the tape recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The outer door opens, Reilly walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly nods, accepts the condolence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry exits. The Bored Cop eyes Reilly suspiciously as Reilly crosses to the other door, yanks it open.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tough? Tough is "Fuck you, where's my lawyer?". This chick doesn't say boo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Captain said I could give it a crack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She ain't no hooker.   This is a murder investigation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was my collar. Maybe I'll get lucky. But, if you got a problem with that, talk to the Captain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   INTERROGATION ROOM                                       27 As Reilly enters, The Girl stiffens at the sight of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly shuts the door, she doesn't respond. The Girl catches a glimpse of his 9mm under his trenchcoat, she's unfazed. He paces, circling her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Girl puts up a good front but we can see she's listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly goes to the table, flicks off the mic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) You know, your boyfriend just killed a ten year old at a bus stop, blew her head clean off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) You're scared. You're just caught in the middle. But, we've got a guy out there wasting people just to get you back. Why? It can't be because of your looks. So, I'll be honest with you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   VIEWING BOOTH                                            28 The Bored Cop doesn't notice, he's engrossed in his comic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   INTERROGATION ROOM                                       29 Reilly sits, the Girl eyes him like a trapped prey. They're enemies, yet there's a strange chemistry between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares, eyes dark, barely registering any emotion at all. A flicker of fear, indecision. Her lips part, fighting it, then she looks away, letting the fear win. Reilly flushes with anger, frustration.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let me be very clear about this. The police won't let you go. When your boyfriend realizes this, I have a feeling a lot of innocent people are going to die. Kids, families. I know you don't want that to happen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   THE CAVE - DAY                                           30 Glass squints through a microscope. Pooch sniffs and fumbles dirt samples. T.J. rocks to a Walkman as he inspects the charred briefcase handle fragment. Bev is at her computer searching luggage websites on the Net. Reilly comes in, still frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Reilly can answer, T.J. rips off his headphones. T.J. Fuckin A, I think I got two partial prints here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They all look over.   Glass stares back darkly. T.J. Glass, what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was wrong... this didn't come from any cash register.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whadaya mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's from an IRA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh shit...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A what? T.J.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We missed you, where'd you go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Awright!   How bout you, Glass, how's that chip shaking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - instant retirement account.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .R.A. device. Deadliest class of tickers in existence. Computerized, multiple sensors, booby traps, the works. First showed up in a series of I.R.A. bombings in London couple years ago. One of their boys tripped it on himself and they went back to a less complicated timers. The Girl, is she Irish?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's not talking. But, she could be. So, obviously, you've seen one of these devices before?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only once, at Redstone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . T.J. That's one more time than any of the rest of us have seen it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit.   We're fucked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relax, Pooch, it's just a ticker, it's not personal. T.J. Let's face it, we all knew it would happen sooner or later. The guy who can build a mousetrap that's better than we are ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop it... T.J. (points to Reilly) And what's he doing to help?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, T.J.!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be nice Pooch! They all explode into a SHOUTING MATCH (except Glass who is in his own world inspecting the microchip an inch from his eyes). A moments mayhem until-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of you, shut the fuck up! They all go silent, stare at Reilly (except Glass).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No wonder the rest of the department doesn't want to work with you. You're nothing but a bunch of... punks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Reilly walks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   POLICE PARKING LOT - AFTERNOON                              31 Reilly goes to his Studebaker, climbs in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   STUDEBAKER                                                  32 As he starts it up, the passenger door rips open.        Glass jumps in, slams the door, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass glares, a challenge.         Glaring back, Reilly guns the engine, screeches away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nice performance back there. Where'd you learn that, Mike Ditka Sensitivity Seminar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No you look, mister! First, you don't go calling my men names. It's bad for morale. Second, us "punks" happen to know a heck of alot more about police work than any vice cop ever did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   ALLEY - AFTERNOON                                           33 The Studebaker rumbles up to the machine shop, parks in the same haunting spot as the night before. Glass and Reilly climb out of the car, flashlights in hand. Reilly glances around, bad memories stirring up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulling out a tool kit, Glass quickly picks the door lock, yanks open the door, ducks inside. Reilly follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The place has already be combed. Forensics pulled over a hundred sets of prints inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then let's go see what they missed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   MACHINE SHOP - AFTERNOON                                34 Nearly pitch dark inside, shafts of late afternoon sunlight glistens on the battered machines. Shadows wash over Reilly and Glass as they retrace the path Reilly and Rice took the night before, Glass searching intensely, Reilly getting more and more uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Top of my class at West Point, thank you very much. Then off to Redstone. First half of the course we learned how to build devices... second half, we'd take them apart. Everything from firecrackers to hydrogen bombs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like terrorist heaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There were a few guys in my class with names like John Smith, Bill Jones. I'd see them up ahead in the hall, call their name, but they wouldn't turn around. C.I.A. Funny thing, they'd always disappear after the first half of the course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just how easy is it to build a... device?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a little training, you could go into a house and just from stuff in the bathroom and kitchen make something that'd finish off that alleged car of yours. Heck, didn't you ever watch MacGyver? Reilly looks at Glass strangely until he realizes they've stopped where Rice died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is where it happened. Reilly fights the memory... eyes well up, his hand trembles ever so slightly as he points out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Girl was here. The guy in charge was over there with one of his men, the other one was back there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Glass gets down on his hands and knees, scans the floor. Reilly talks to distract himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bombers, what kettle of fish are they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Typical profile, usually losers, nobodies that're afraid to confront their victims. They like scaring people. That's why they call in their threats. Same mentality as obscene phone callers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Except they'll blow you up if you don't play along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, ninety-ninety percent of them are full of baloney. They're into the power trip, not the damage. What scares me is that this guy is so sophisticated he could blow up whatever he wants, then disappear. The worst of the bunch, they love the challenge of creating the wildest device ever... and they love the carnage. Glass lays out flat on his stomach and searches deep under a machine, picks up a half-smoked cigarette butt with tweezers, pulls it out, kneels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. Glass straightens it out, reads the brand name, "Gallois".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: French. Doubt somebody who worked here smoked it. Only half gone, put it out in a hurry. (glances around) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass takes off.   Reilly follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So what were they doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. You tell me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An abandoned machine shop... nice place to build devices. Low rent, too. But, you and Rice ruined their perfect hideout.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Redstone's the army training center in Alabama where they send the cream of the crop to learn about tickers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cream of the crop, huh?   You?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) Figuring the length, assuming it was one of these guys, odds are... it was lit outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   MACHINE SHIP - GARAGE - AFTERNOON                         35 Glass and Reilly search the area.    Glass moves on his knees, aiming the flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass pinches something with his tweezers, holds it up triumphantly... a used match.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is where the van was parked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then, it's gotta be here somewhere ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: UP - MATCH UNDER MICROSCOPE A jungle of giant fibers teeming with strange molecules. T.J. (O.C.) No question, it was definitely the one used to l-light the butt. Finger pressure suggests a male, average build, height... no prints, trace of nylon fiber... he wore a glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   THE CAVE - AFTERNOON                                      36 T.J. punches keys on a computer, peers through the microscope as Glass, Reilly, Pooch and Bev stand by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . T.J. This is strange. Two computer screens - one displays the magnified match from different angles, the other spills out a stream of formulae and chemical breakdowns. T.J. (cont.) (reading info) Three foreign particles ... vulcanized rubber ... resin ... nitro-cellulose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nitro-cellulose. What is that, some kind of explosive?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Industrial wood oil. Separately, any one of these things could lead in several directions, but together ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ka-Boooom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They make bowling balls out of vulcanized rubber ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Resin... T.J. Lane oil...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bowling alley. At an adjacent computer, Bev runs a scan program on the match, comparing it against an endless stream of match types on file. Schnoz howls awake from a nap as T.J. stabs the screen as a match is made, specifications filling the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . T.J. Got it! Ace Match Company, Flint, Michigan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly mouth is opened, duly impressed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (amazed) You mean you just--? ... You keep a record of... matches?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, matches are a very big thing in our line of work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bev, give `em a call, find out what bowling alleys they supply in this area.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pooch, why don't you e-mail your buddies at Langley and on the other side of the pond, see if any IRAs been popping up lately?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Reilly) We work fast enough for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   BOWLING ALLEY - LATE AFTERNOON                           37 The Studebaker and Harley swerve up to a run-down, windowless bowling alley, park in a red zone. Reilly and T.J, climb out of the clunker, Glass off his bike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . T.J. checks his hair in the side mirror, sniffs his underarms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly and Glass exchange a grin, they drag T.J. inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .J., what're you doing? T.J. My first undercover assignment. I gotta look good, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   BOWLING ALLEY - LATE AFTERNOON                          38 A busy Saturday afternoon crowd. Rock music blasts, reverberating with the echo of crashing balls and pins. The lanes are teeming with sweating bodies. Sexy waitresses in skimpy outfits deliver drinks. T.J. ogles women as they wander through. T.J. So what're we looking for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly and Glass nod, knowing it's a longshot. Reilly directs Glass and T.J. to split up to case the place. They move through the rowdy crowd, eyes catching every smoker.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Someone who smokes French cigarettes. T.J. In this crowd? It's gonna be Marlboros, Camels, and maybe a few Kools.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BOWLING ALLEY - POOL ROOM/BAR - LATER                     39 The music is more redneck-rock, the crowd as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Glass and T.J. are in the midst of game of pool, nursing bottles of Root Beer. They continue to play while eyeing those coming and going. Reilly enters from the alley, catches Glass' eye and shakes his head. He goes to the bar and orders a coke. He takes the drink and moves over next to Glass as T.J. lines up a shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long are we going to stay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Til we get a better lead. Reilly's attention is drawn to a crowded booth in the corner where a few bowling alley girls block the view of the entire booth. Glass nudges Reilly, they look over to see Pooch entering the bar. He sees them and moves to the bar. T.J. sinks his shot and lines up another as Reilly and Glass move to meet Pooch. Pooch produces a printout from his jacket, opens it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unsolved bombings in the last year... Boston, New York, Philadelphia... but no real match
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Insurance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Political.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly my thinking. Except, none of the targets can actually be linked to government, political or special interest concerns. They seem to be just unrelated industrial companies.   Some insured, some not. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But there's traces of C4 and assorted inflammatory additives found in each case. The only common denominator is the detonators all had circuitry consistent with our micro- chip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad for Bomb squad, eh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What not bad. You've got a series of bombs, devices, that may or may not be connected, set by one or many nutjobs, who may or may not be linked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... it's more than we had ten minutes ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a friend over at Scotland Yard who's gonna try and reach out to a undercover guy who would know if any of the rightwingers are circulating over here. Bev's following up on the briefcase manufacturers, too. T.J. comes over. T.J. Pooch, you're up.    Rack `em. They look over to the pool table to see only the cue ball left. T.J. (cont.) Boss, you're buying the next round. T.J. sets his empty Root Beer bottle on the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How're you guys doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still waiting for a miracle.   Go ahead. Pooch and T.J. head back to the pool table where two comely Gals have begun putting the balls back onto the table. T.J. turns on his smile and chats them up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite a team you've got, where'd you find them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a small fraternity, everyone knows everyone. I'm always recruiting. Pooch is ex- D.O.D., military expert... claymores, grenades. He played linebacker at Boston College, worked a K-9 unit - that led him to the Bomb Squad... great nose, lousy fingers, we try to keep him away from the tickers. T.J. is a heck of chemist, Texas A&M engineering degree. Found him in a Militia chat room - turns out we were both monitoring the same groups. Bev is the natural born hacker, we stole her from dispatch. She had the Cave reorganized and ultra-high-tech in two months. Captain has no idea how much hardware she's "found" for us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You guys seem pretty tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've gotta be. In this business, you don't exactly make alot of outside commitments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, it's strange... it's not the best career path, but when you get the bug, there's nothing you can do about it.   See, when you beat one of these things... (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: there's that one second when you realize you saw something you weren't supposed to see... this beautiful naked woman... Death... and then the rush comes, the high, cuz you realize you got away with it. T.J. returns, shrugs. T.J. Lesbians. Pooch is still with the girls, showing one of them how to line up a shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like Pooch's doing okay. T.J. He's married, he don't even know what a lesbian is. T.J. waves over the Bartender. He and Glass orders fresh drinks as Reilly eyes pretty Blonde across the bar. She picks up two beers and grabs a pack of matches off the bar. She turns and moves to the booth in the corner.   The bodies part and Reilly catches a glimpse of Earring. Reilly nearly chokes on his coke as Earring takes the matches from the Blonde. Earring checks his watches, rises. He looks up and catches Reilly's eye - he smiles--then bolts. Reilly coughs up his drink and tries to get a word out, pointing as Earring slips out the exit door next to the booth. Glass pats Reilly's back as he gags, eyes blazing. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There he goes. He was here the whole time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Reilly pushes his way through the crowd with Glass on his heels. T.J. rushes over and grabs Pooch away from the Girls at the pool table. Reilly runs into a pair of enormous Rednecks, spilling their beer on them. The Rednecks grab him by the collar and prepare to fight as Pooch arrives and body-blocks the Rednecks away from Reilly. Reilly is released and he continues after Earring as Pooch and the Rednecks mix it up. A brawl breaks out with Pooch and T.J. in the middle as Reilly and Glass make it to the exit door. Reilly flies out- but Glass FREEZES dead in his tracks. He spins back to look at the corner booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits on the floor under the table. Glass tenses. The fight escalates quickly, but Pooch employs his linebacker skills and cuts down his assailant... and T.J. a natural streetfighting-rabbit-puncher. They quickly dispatch the Rednecks, leaving them bruised and bloodied... they rush for Glass and the doorway--then lock on Glass' reaction and stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - LATE AFTERNOON                                    40 Reilly runs out into the middle of the street. At the end of the block, Earring is rushing for the corner. Reilly draws his 9mm, aims thru the pedestrian--and fires. Earring is blown off his feet... He hits the pavement hard...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BAR                                                     41 Reilly enters and sees Glass, TJ and Pooch gathered around the booth in back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bomb squad ignores Reilly, who now realizes something is wrong. He pushes his way through the bar patrons to the booth. Glass glances up at Reilly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Say, thanks for the back up--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and Pooch exchange looks--they've never heard Glass so close to swearing before. T.J. notices a small crowd starting to gather around the booth. T.J. (calmly) Clear the area, please. Nobody moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That does it, the crowds shriek and scatter. Rolling eyes at each other, the Bomb Squaders turn their attention to the shopping bag sitting on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The team eyes the package for a moment...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Glass makes a determination, whips out a knife, slashes the bag open, revealing a computerized nightmare of a bomb inside.   T.J. rubs his temples with dread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Glass puts on his magnifying spectacles, starts to probe. Reilly returns. Pooch tests hinges with his tweezers. T.J. hands Glass a crimp. Pooch pries off a back panel, fingers shaking, lifts it every so slightly, sees complex circuitry inside, the red glow of a digital readout counting down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh shit... T.J. Fuck factor ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I'm going in, nobody breathe. Synchronizing his chronometer to the counter, Glass begins disengaging sensor switches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Altimeter... choking coil... mercury switch... He clips off circuits and booby traps with bloodcurdling care, peeling away layer after layer of death... shakes his head with awe, respect, fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Triple V.O.M... brilliant... this guy's a master... Finally he comes to the heart of the bomb, a pair of tiny wires leading to the blasting cap, one yellow, one red. Precious seconds tick away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's one of these wires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So cut both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One shuts it down, one turns arms it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which one's which?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. There's an old saying, when in doubt, cut the yellow wire. Reilly gulps. The device teeters, slightly, alarming T.J. and Pooch. Glass nods. T.J. and Pooch each grab a corner of the device to steady it. Reilly follows their lead and kneels, goes to reach for a corner as well, one hand starts to tremble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can go back to the van if you like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm with you. Reilly focuses and wills his hands to steady.    He grabs a corner and closes his eyes, mind over matter.    Sweat streams as he concentrates like never before. Pooch and T.J. stare at the wires with intensity.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (loudly) You heard him, get the fuck away, it's a bomb!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: seconds, 14, 13,... Glass pulls out a clipper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... He eases the clipper into position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... He draws in a breath. Closing his eyes, he clips the yellow wire.    Reilly's eyes snap open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The counter stops on 4 - no explosion. Pooch and T.J. whoop and hug like drunk madmen.   Glass steps away, stone-faced. Reilly follows him, wobbly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Is this a great job or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   STREET - MOMENTS LATER                                   42 Two squad cars have appeared, Officers cordon off the crime scene. Glass watches Reilly kneeling over Earring's body digging through Earring's pockets, finding nothing but cash, cigarettes and matches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pooch and T.J. have the device on the ground a few feet away from the Earring's body. They delicately continue to take it apart so it can be transported safely. Schnoz sits nearby, watching. Pooch is on the phone with his wife...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he says this, he lifts a chunk of C4 and sets it aside. Pooch hangs up his phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, honey. I'll see. No, everything's fine, it was nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pooch and TJ exit the bar, moving to Glass and Reilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. Glass notes Reilly's hands.

direction.raw_text: Pooch scribbles down an address on a scrap of paper from the device's shopping bag, hands it to Reilly, offering a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly looks at it awkwardly, then walks away as a News van arrives on the scene...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) You guys hungry? The wife's got a heap of lasagna leftover. T.J. (at Reilly) What do ay say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) Good meal would go a long way to steady your system.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got work to do, don't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In case you change your mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ./INT. DOWNTOWN - STUDEBAKER - EARLY EVENING                43 Reilly cruises into the bowels of downtown.    Makes a few turns and parks. In the shadows of a burned out building, Reilly observes several JUNKIES getting a fix from their CONNECTION. Reilly watches with scared, tempted eyes. He looks at his hands... they're trembling... catches his reflection in the rear view mirror. Checks Rice's watches on his wrist, taps it. Still not ticking. Ashamed, he screeches away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POLICE STATION - OFFICE - NIGHT                           44 A quiet Squad Room. Reilly bangs out something on a computer terminal. He blazes away, typing as fast as he can. He holds out his hands. Almost steady. He takes a drink from a Protein Shake, returns to typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   WINTERS' OFFICE - NIGHT                                 45 A weary Winters looks up from coffee and paperwork as Reilly knocks, walks in. Reilly drops a sheaf of papers on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly nods, accepting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly nods, turns and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Report on the case so far.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know after a shooting I would normally take your badge and weapon, but Glass called in already and confirmed it was clean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But from now on, any leads on this case go to Pluchinsky. He's primary investigator and you are unofficially assigned to the Bomb Squad... you and your new friends are not to be playing detective any more. Got it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) I imagine as soon as they find out one of their's is dead, we'll be getting another call. So get some sleep, alright.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   SUNCREST MOTEL - ROOM - NIGHT                           46 TIGHT on a TV - a pretty Reporter reports live from the scene...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: To recap, a gunman carrying what police described as a phony bomb was shot and killed less than an hour ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Swan watches the TV report with Beard, eyes narrowing as he sees Reilly in the crowd behind the Reporter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swan kicks in the TV, destroying it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swan flips open a suitcase full of bomb-making materials and begins to sort through...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) While the man's motives and identity remain a mystery, police are denying the incident is related to the explosion that ripped through a bar earlier today, killing 15 and wounding more than 30...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   POOCH'S HOUSE - NIGHT                                   47 Quiet, cozy, middle class. The Harley and the Bomb Squad van are parked out front. Also the Studebaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   POOCH'S HOUSE - HALLWAY - NIGHT                         48 Reilly exits the bathroom, returns to the dining room where the Bomb Squad is laughing, hoeing and haying over dessert. Pooch's faithful wife, MEG, pours coffee. TOMMY and JANIE, Pooch's kids, sit on Pooch's and T.J.'s knees, in their pajamas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More coffee, T.J.? T.J. No thanks, Meg. Hawed Pooch ever get so lucky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Reilly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike.   No thanks, I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time for bed, kiddos.   Say goodnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can Uncle Teej tuck us in? T.J. C'mon, champ, I'll even give you a piggyback.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight Uncle Charlie, goodnight Uncle Mike. Janie surprises Reilly with a shy kiss, scurries upstairs with after Pooch, T.J. and Tommy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Night... Meg clears the dishes, Schnoz is asleep on the floor. Glass and Reilly are left alone.   Reilly takes a sip of coffee, hand trembles ever so slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long were you hooked?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to talk about it. Reilly stares, then opens up slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pittsburgh, two years ago. Partner died, no back-up, I was too gung-ho. As usual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a tip from the Bomb Boys, always assess, if only for a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. I was working a drug ring, deep cover. Played the part too well. When they pulled me out, I wasn't a cop anymore. My fiance had dumped me. Next thing I knew, I was out here on the street, doped up, auditioning for the morgue when this tough old vice cop found me, cleaned me up, gave me a second chance. He promised Captain Winters he'd look out for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your partner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I didn't realize how much I needed him. He kept me straight. It's been tough every second since. Reilly holds up his wristwatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This was his. Doesn't work for shit, but it's keeping me straight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Reilly gives him the watch. Glass pulls out a mini tool kit, pries off the back of the watch examines the works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out the mini-kit. Reilly takes it uncertainly, but follows Glass' instructions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly gives it a tweak, looks at the watch, surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly throws Glass a surprised look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) Main spring's stuck. All you have to do is free the palate and realign the balance wheel. Here, you try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No you're not, you just don't understand them. Here, do what I tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont.) Okay, first push the pin back with this. Good. Now while you keep it there, stick this in here and turn it slowly. Easy, that's it. Now let the pin go and line up the wheel. That should do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Congratulations, you just built your first ticker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   POOCH'S HOUSE - EARLY MORNING                           49 Sunrise breaking. Reilly and Glass have their heads under the hood of the Studebaker, covered in grease, tools everywhere. T.J. sits behind the wheel. Pooch and Schnoz stumble out of the house to watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: T.J. guns the engine, the Studebaker purrs like a tiger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glass glances at Pooch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Alright! T.J. We've created a monster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing.    Maybe they gave up, split town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One partial from the handle matches the suspect from last night. Name's Carl Taylor. Long record of arson, assault, the works. The other print - we got nothing from our data base or the FBI or CIA... still waiting for Interpol.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   WINTERS' OFFICE - MORNING                                53 Reilly walks in. Winters gestures for him to take a seat as he talks on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Winters hangs up.

direction.raw_text: I got a call from upstairs. They say you questioned the girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't.     But I had to try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly, I think I've shown that I'm a patient man. Rice was your biggest fan and I've tried to honor him by giving you some slack. But you are very close to running out of slack.

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Winters lets this sink in, then holds up Reilly's report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I read your report. Impressive. I'd say it's got detective written all over it. But... you cross the line one more time... you're gone. Are we clear? Reilly, nods, shifts uncomfortably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, that out of the way. The girl wants to talk to you, alone. Reilly is shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So get going, let's close this thing.

dialogue.raw_text: Yes ... no, of course not but ... yes, sir, I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Reilly nods, Harry exits.     Reilly sits down at the table opposite her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seems relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary takes a deep breath, eyes welling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly rises and moves to her.   Their eyes linger a moment, a bond between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reilly nods and touches her shoulder, a light squeeze.   He turns and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Mary Jordan. We were hired to take out some industrial sites. Insurance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cover. (slowly, ashamed) It was suppose to be abandoned buildings, y'know. No one was suppose to get hurt. The night you busted us...We were checking to make sure there weren't any vagrants around. Scare them away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alex Swan. My brother. The other two are called Taylor and Leveau.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is a motel downtown, near the Machine Shop... the Suncrest. Room 138.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: mayhem as the team floods into the room. Pluchinsky brings up the rear. After a beat, Pluchinsky re- emerges, shaking his head.

The Bag Lady scribbles down his license number in her pad. Glass follows Reilly's stare.

dialogue.raw_text: Lemme see... yeah, here it is, 11:18 this morning. Very disrespectful. He used to drive a van, but he got a new car. You want the license number?

dialogue.raw_text: Alex Swan - demolitions expert, trained at Redstone, dropped out, freelanced in the middle East for awhile, then disappeared, no criminal record. The other one, Leveau, is French Canadian, he's a mercenary, record in half a dozen countries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   LET HER GO NOW... OR A BOMB'S COMING CLOSE TO HOME."

dialogue.raw_text: (V.0) ... suspects driving a dark green Ford Grenada, license number one Two Eight Michael Vincent Edward ...

direction.raw_text: . POLICE STATION - SQUAD ROOM - DAY                         59 In the squad room, Pluchinsky and some men wait anxiously by phones, computer-consoles, radio switchboard.

direction.raw_text: . POLICE STATION - DAY                                     60 Reilly idles in his Studebaker. T.J. and Pooch come out of the parking lot in the Bomb Squad Van, Glass motors along side Reilly. He guns the bike and takes the lead, followed by Reilly, then the van. They pull out into traffic and head towards the suburbs.

dialogue.raw_text: Glass, there they are. Pooch right in front of you, you got `em, you got `em.

direction.raw_text: . STREET - DAY                                             63 Reilly SKIDS to a dead stop. Glass, up ahead tries to maneuver around slowing cars as... The Grenada speeds down a street right in front of the Bomb Squad Van. Pooch cranks into a turn and gives chase. Reilly and Glass are pinned in by other cars. They both finally squeeze out of their jams in different directions...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./INT. ANOTHER STREET - BOMB SQUAD VAN - DAY                 64 An excited T.J. jumps on the radio. T.J. Dispatch, this is Bomb Squad. Suspects sighted on Fern Street, two blocks from HQ. In pursuit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - DAY                                               65 Beard speeds around another corner, the lumbering Van has difficulty keeping up and loses sight of the Grenada for a moment.
